focus_skills: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 12 from both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Then divide both sides by 5: <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations in reverse order of operations.

questions.question: A bookstore offers a 25% discount on all books. If a book originally costs $48, what is the sale price after the discount?
questions.explanation: The discount amount is <math><mn>25</mn><mi>%</mi></math> of <math><mn>48</mn></math>, which is <math><mn>0.25</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. The sale price is <math><mn>48</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> dollars.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that the sale price = original price − discount amount. Alternatively, calculate sale price directly as (100% − discount%) × original price.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe requires 3 cups of flour for every 2 cups of sugar. If a baker uses 9 cups of flour, how many cups of sugar are needed?
questions.explanation: Set up a proportion: <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></math>. Cross-multiply: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When working with ratios, set up a proportion and solve by cross-multiplication.

questions.question: A rectangular garden has a length of 15 meters and a width of 8 meters. What is the area, in square meters, of the garden?
questions.explanation: The area of a rectangle is length × width: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math> square meters.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize basic area formulas: rectangle = length × width, triangle = ½ × base × height, circle = πr².

questions.question: The line represented by the equation <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math> is shifted up 4 units. What is the equation of the new line?
questions.explanation: Shifting a line up by 4 units means adding 4 to the y-intercept. The original y-intercept is -7, so the new y-intercept is -7 + 4 = -3. The slope remains unchanged. The new equation is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: A vertical shift affects the constant term (y-intercept) in the equation y = mx + b.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='45' y='220' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>0</text><line x1='150' y1='250' x2='150' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='145' y='220' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>20</text><line x1='250' y1='250' x2='250' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='245' y='220' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>40</text><line x1='350' y1='250' x2='350' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='345' y='220' font-size='12' text-anchor='end'>60</text><text x='200' y='280' font-size='14'>Number of Books Read</text><rect x='60' y='150' width='80' height='100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='160' y='50' width='80' height='200' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='260' y='100' width='80' height='150' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='100' y='145' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='200' y='45' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>10</text><text x='300' y='95' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>8</text><text x='100' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>10-19</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>20-29</text><text x='300' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>40-49</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Histogram with three bins. The bin for 10-19 books has frequency 5, the bin for 20-29 books has frequency 10, and the bin for 40-49 books has frequency 8.
questions.question: The histogram above shows the distribution of the number of books read by students in a summer reading program. What is the total number of students represented in the histogram?
questions.explanation: Add the frequencies from each bar: <math><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>23</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For histograms, the total count is found by summing the heights (frequencies) of all bars.

questions.question: Which of the following is a solution to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Set each factor equal to zero: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math>; <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Among the choices, 2 is a solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratic equations, try factoring first. Look for two numbers that multiply to the constant term and add to the coefficient of the linear term.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 300,80' fill='lightgray' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='90' y='210' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='310' y='210' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='310' y='70' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='180' font-size='14'>10</text><text x='320' y='140' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='180' y='120' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='110' y='190' font-size='16' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>θ</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle ABC, with right angle at B. Side AB (horizontal) is length 10. Side BC (vertical) is length 6. Side AC is hypotenuse, labeled x. Angle A is labeled θ.
questions.question: In right triangle ABC shown, angle A is labeled θ, AB = 10, and BC = 6. What is the value of tan(θ)?
questions.explanation: In a right triangle, tan(θ) = opposite / adjacent relative to angle θ. For angle A, the opposite side is BC = 6, and the adjacent side is AB = 10. Therefore, <math><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: SOH CAH TOA: Sine = Opposite/Hypotenuse, Cosine = Adjacent/Hypotenuse, Tangent = Opposite/Adjacent.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add the two equations to eliminate y: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving systems, look for opportunities to add or subtract equations to eliminate one variable.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels 270 miles in 4.5 hours. What is its average speed, in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time = <math><mn>270</mn><mo>÷</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> miles per hour.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Average speed is total distance divided by total time. Make sure units are consistent.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the numerator: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Then <math><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, provided <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look to factor numerators and denominators in rational expressions to simplify. Remember to note domain restrictions.

questions.question: A bag contains 5 red marbles, 7 blue marbles, and 8 green marbles. If one marble is chosen at random, what is the probability that it is NOT blue?
questions.explanation: Total marbles = 5 + 7 + 8 = 20. Number of marbles that are NOT blue = 5 (red) + 8 (green) = 13. Probability = <math><mfrac><mn>13</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Probability of an event not happening is 1 minus the probability of it happening. You can also count favorable outcomes directly.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='120' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='285' y='155' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='115' y='155' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='200' y='140' font-size='14'>O</text><text x='240' y='140' font-size='14'>4</text><text x='160' y='140' font-size='14'>4</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Circle with center O. Points A and B lie on the circle on a horizontal diameter. OA = OB = 4.
questions.question: In the circle with center O shown above, points A and B lie on the circle such that AB is a diameter. If the length of OA is 4, what is the circumference of the circle?
questions.explanation: OA is a radius of the circle, so radius r = 4. The circumference is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Key circle formulas: Circumference = 2πr, Area = πr², where r is the radius.

questions.question: Which number line represents the solution to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math>?

options.A: A closed circle at 5, shaded to the left.
options.B: A closed circle at 5, shaded to the right.
options.C: A closed circle at 15/3, shaded to the left.
options.D: A closed circle at 15/3, shaded to the right.

questions.explanation: Solve the inequality: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. This means all numbers less than or equal to 5. On a number line, this is a closed circle at 5 with shading to the left.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When graphing inequalities on a number line: < or > use an open circle; ≤ or ≥ use a closed circle. Shade in the direction of the inequality.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><path d='M 50 250 Q 200 50 350 250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='200' y='40' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>Vertex (h, k)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Parabola opening upwards. A dashed horizontal line goes through the vertex, and a dashed vertical line goes through the vertex. The vertex is labeled (h, k).
questions.question: The graph of the quadratic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math> is a parabola. If the parabola opens upward and its vertex has a positive x-coordinate and a negative y-coordinate, which of the following must be true?

options.D: <math><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and the vertex is in quadrant IV.

questions.explanation: The parabola opens upward, so the leading coefficient <math><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The vertex has a negative y-coordinate (k < 0). The y-intercept of the parabola is f(0) = c. Since the vertex is below the x-axis and the parabola opens upward, it must cross the y-axis below the x-axis as well, meaning c < 0.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Connect graph features to algebraic properties: opening direction ↔ sign of a, y-intercept ↔ value of c, vertex x-coordinate ↔ -b/(2a).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='50' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='280' font-size='14'>Time Studying (hours)</text><text x='20' y='150' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90,20,150)'>Test Score</text><circle cx='100' cy='200' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='150' cy='180' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='250' cy='120' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='300' cy='100' r='4' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot with 5 points showing a strong negative linear relationship between Time Studying and Test Score.
questions.question: A scatterplot shows the relationship between the number of hours a student studies per week and their test score. Based on the pattern shown, if a line of best fit were drawn, what would be the sign of its slope?
questions.explanation: The scatterplot shows that as the number of hours studying (x) increases, the test score (y) decreases. This indicates a negative relationship, so the slope of the line of best fit would be negative.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In a scatterplot, if y tends to decrease as x increases, the slope is negative. If y tends to increase as x increases, the slope is positive.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math><mi>m</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants. If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>m</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a linear function, the slope m is given by the change in f(x) divided by the change in x. <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a linear function f(x) = mx + b, the slope m = (change in y) / (change in x) between any two points.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: Water is being pumped into a tank at a constant rate. After 20 minutes, the tank contains 180 gallons of water. After 35 minutes, the tank contains 315 gallons of water. At this rate, how many gallons of water were in the tank before the pumping started?
questions.explanation: Let V₀ be the initial volume and r be the pumping rate. From the given data: V₀ + 20r = 180 and V₀ + 35r = 315. Subtract the first equation from the second: (V₀ + 35r) - (V₀ + 20r) = 315 - 180 → 15r = 135 → r = 9. Substitute r = 9 into the first equation: V₀ + 20×9 = 180 → V₀ + 180 = 180 → V₀ = 0.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For linear rate problems, set up the equation: Final amount = Initial amount + (rate × time). Use two data points to solve for the two unknowns.

questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system: Multiply the second equation by 3: <math><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>57</mn></math>. Add to the first equation: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>57</mn></math> → <math><mn>14</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>74</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>14</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. Substitute into first equation: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>119</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>45</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. Then <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>52</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sometimes it's faster to solve for a+b directly by manipulating the equations rather than solving for a and b separately.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 200,80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='80' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='210' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='305' y='210' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='70' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='200' y='210' font-size='14'>D</text><text x='180' y='140' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='220' y='140' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='16' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>x°</text><text x='250' y='190' font-size='16' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Isosceles triangle ABC with vertex A at top. AD is the altitude to base BC, splitting it into two equal segments BD and DC, each of length 6. Angles at B and C are each labeled x°.
questions.question: In isosceles triangle ABC shown, AB = AC, and AD is an altitude to base BC. If BD = 6 and angle ABC = 60°, what is the length of AB?
questions.explanation: Since triangle ABC is isosceles with AB = AC and angle ABC = 60°, triangle ABC is equilateral (all angles 60°). In an equilateral triangle, all sides are equal. The altitude AD bisects the base BC, so BC = 2 × BD = 2 × 6 = 12. Therefore, AB = BC = 12.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In isosceles triangles, the altitude to the base creates two congruent right triangles. Use Pythagorean theorem or special right triangle ratios if angles are known.
